ES

Musical instruments in worship

The use of musical instruments was one of the characteristics of worship that the people of Israel presented to God while living under the law given to Moses.
Subsequently, JesusChrist revealed the true manner to worship, while the former - being only a shadow of the truth - is annulled, including amongst other things, the use of instruments.
Now, in the time of grace, Christ establishes spiritual worship. In effect, the use of instruments in worship — apart from having no use in spiritual praise — is prohibited by the Lord.

John 4 : 20-24

20 Our fathers worshiped on this mountain, but you Jews claim that the place where we must worship is in Jerusalem.
21 Jesus declared, "Believe me, woman, a time is coming when you will worship the Father neither on this mountain nor in Jerusalem.
22 You Samaritans worship what you do not know; we worship what we do know, for salvation is from the Jews.
23 Yet a time is coming and has now come when the true worshipers will worship the Father in spirit and truth, for they are the kind of worshipers the Father seeks.
24 God is spirit, and his worshipers must worship in spirit and in truth."

Worship under the law ▾

Christ affirms that salvation comes from the Jews supporting the notion that the city of Jerusalem was in fact the correct place to worship.

John 4 : 20

20 Our fathers worshiped on this mountain, but you Jews claim that the place where we must worship is in Jerusalem.

John 4 : 22

22 You Samaritans worship what you do not know; we worship what we do know, for salvation is from the Jews.

Jerusalem: place of worship

God chooses Jerusalem as the site of his sanctuary.

2 Chronicles 6 : 5-6

5 'Since the day I brought my people out of Egypt, I have not chosen a city in any tribe of Israel to have a temple built for my Name to be there, nor have I chosen anyone to be the leader over my people Israel.
6 But now I have chosen Jerusalem for my Name to be there, and I have chosen David to rule my people Israel.'

2 Chronicles 6 : 20

20 May your eyes be open toward this temple day and night, this place of which you said you would put your Name there. May you hear the prayer your servant prays toward this place.

Even while in captivity, the people of Israel lamented for not being able to sing songs in a place that was far from the holy city.

Psalm 137 : 4

4 How can we sing the songs of the LORD while in a foreign land?

Israel worships with instruments

The levites and priests were the ones that played instruments during the offerings.
The playing of instruments would only last till the end of the sacrifice that was offered.

2 Chronicles 29 : 25-29

25 He stationed the Levites in the temple of the LORD with cymbals, harps and lyres in the way prescribed by David and Gad the king's seer and Nathan the prophet; this was commanded by the LORD through his prophets.
26 So the Levites stood ready with David's instruments, and the priests with their trumpets.
27 Hezekiah gave the order to sacrifice the burnt offering on the altar. As the offering began, singing to the LORD began also, accompanied by trumpets and the instruments of David king of Israel.
28 The whole assembly bowed in worship, while the singers sang and the trumpeters played. All this continued until the sacrifice of the burnt offering was completed.
29 When the offerings were finished, the king and everyone present with him knelt down and worshiped.

Worship in time of grace ▾

Christ declares that Jerusalen would no longer be the place to worship God for the time of grace had begun with his coming.

John 4 : 21

21 Jesus declared, "Believe me, woman, a time is coming when you will worship the Father neither on this mountain nor in Jerusalem.

God seeks the true and spiritual adoration. The old way of worshipping was not acceptable before God. Therefore it would not continue.

John 4 : 23

23 Yet a time is coming and has now come when the true worshipers will worship the Father in spirit and truth, for they are the kind of worshipers the Father seeks.

The act of worship that was done in Jerusalem was carnal and material. Even the sanctuary in Jerusalem was constructed mainly to accomodate the physical elements that were used in the ritual.

Hebrews 9 : 1

1 Now the first covenant had regulations for worship and also an earthly sanctuary.

Establishment of spiritual worship

Being the fulfiller of the law, Christ annulls the law to establish a new pact. Through this act, the ritual of worship under the law is terminated, signifying the end of sacrificial offerings that were accompanied by the playing of instruments.

Hebrews 10 : 1

1 The law is only a shadow of the good things that are coming--not the realities themselves. For this reason it can never, by the same sacrifices repeated endlessly year after year, make perfect those who draw near to worship.

Hebrews 10 : 9

9 Then he said, "Here I am, I have come to do your will." He sets aside the first to establish the second.

Those that try to worship with the use of instruments fall under a curse for wanting to live in the works of the law.

Galatians 3 : 10

10 All who rely on observing the law are under a curse, for it is written: "Cursed is everyone who does not continue to do everything written in the Book of the Law."

Spiritual worship

John 4 : 24

24 God is spirit, and his worshipers must worship in spirit and in truth."

The Apostol refers to the church as a holy priesthood, free to offer spiritual sacrifices to God. Under this new pact, the church will have the opportunity to present sacrifices to God in praise and worship.

1 Peter 2 : 5

5 you also, like living stones, are being built into a spiritual house to be a holy priesthood, offering spiritual sacrifices acceptable to God through Jesus Christ.

Singing as Sacrifice of praise

One of the characteristics of the church of Christ is the spiritual and mindful offering of songs through voice, just as Christ and his Apostles did without instruments.

Matthew 26 : 30

30 When they had sung a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.

Hebrews 13 : 15

15 Through Jesus, therefore, let us continually offer to God a sacrifice of praise--the fruit of lips that confess his name.

1 Corinthias 14 : 15

15 Through Jesus, therefore, let us continually offer to God a sacrifice of praise--the fruit of lips that confess his name.
